verses.text: 神的必將被擄以色列啊！不要歡喜；不要像外族人一樣快樂，因為你行了邪淫，離開你的 神，在各打穀場上喜愛賣淫的賞賜。

words.note: Often preceded by a space for reverence in some Bible translations.
Refers to non-Israelites.
Often refers to spiritual idolatry and unfaithfulness to God.
Often preceded by a space for reverence in some Bible translations.

verses.text: 打穀場和榨酒池不能餵養他們，新酒也必使他們失望。
他們必不得住在耶和華之地；以法蓮要回到埃及去，要在亞述吃不潔之物。

words.note: Archaic equivalent of '的'.
Refers to the tribe and territory of Ephraim.
Archaic equivalent of '的'.

verses.heading: Assyrian Exile Will Reverse the Egyptian Exodus

verses.text: 他們必不得向耶和華奠酒，他們的祭物也不能使他喜悅。他們的餅好像喪家的餅，凡吃這餅的，都必被玷污；因為他們的餅只可自己吃，不可帶進耶和華的殿。

words.note: Refers to a family in mourning, traditionally considered ritually unclean.

verses.text: 那麼，在規定集會的日子和耶和華節期的時候，你們能作甚麼？
看哪！即使他們從毀滅中逃去，埃及要收殮他們，摩弗要埋葬他們。他們珍貴的銀器必為蒺藜所佔有，他們的帳棚必長滿荊棘。

words.note: Often introduces an important statement or command.
Used after a noun to denote 'in the midst of'.
Specifically refers to preparing a body for burial.
Often used in the Bible to describe barrenness or curses.
Forms passive voice with 為/被.
Refers to portable dwellings, prominent in ancient Israel.

words.definition: to be covered with, full of

words.note: Similar to 蒺藜, symbolizing desolation or difficulty.

verses.heading: No Escape for the Israelites This Time!

verses.text: 懲罰的日子臨近，報應的時候來到，以色列必定知道，因著你們眾多的罪孽和深仇大恨，先知被看為愚昧，受靈感動的人被當作瘋子。

words.note: Often used in religious contexts for divine judgment.
Emphasizes the evil nature and consequence of sin.
Idiomatic expression for intense, long-standing enmity.
Lit. 'one who knows beforehand'.
Refers to being moved or inspired by the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: 先知與 神一同作以法蓮的守望者，在他所行的一切路上，都滿有捕鳥人的網羅，在他 神的家中只有仇恨。

words.note: The leading space '　' is a reverential mark in some Bibles.
所 + V often means 'that which is V-ed'.
Figuratively, a trap or scheme.
The leading space '　' is a reverential mark in some Bibles.

verses.heading: Israel Rejects Hosea’s Prophetic Exhortations

verses.text: 以法蓮深深敗壞，如同在基比亞的日子一般。 神必記得他們的罪孽，懲罰他們的罪惡。

words.note: The leading space '　' is a reverential mark in some Bibles.

verses.heading: The Best of Times, the Worst of Times

verses.text: 「我遇見以色列，好像在曠野裡遇見葡萄。我看見你們的列祖，像看見無花果樹初熟的果子。他們卻來到巴力．毗珥，專作羞恥的事，成為可憎惡的，像他們所愛的偶像一樣。

words.note: Used as a locative suffix, indicating 'inside'.
Lit. 'flowerless fruit tree', referring to its obscure flowers.
A Moabite deity worshipped at Peor.

words.definition: to dedicate to, to specialize in
words.note: Implies doing something exclusively or intently.
Describes something deeply repulsive or sinful.
所 + V often means 'that which is V-ed'.

verses.text: 至於以法蓮，他們的榮耀必如鳥兒飛逝；沒有生育，沒有懷胎，沒有成孕。

words.note: Refers to the northern kingdom of Israel.

verses.heading: The Fertility Worshipers Will Become Infertile

verses.text: 即使他們把兒女養大，我也必使他們喪子，一個不留。我離棄他們的時候，他們就有禍了。」

words.definition: to be in trouble, suffer misfortune

verses.text: 在我看來，以法蓮的兒女註定被當作獵物；以法蓮要把自己的兒女帶出來，交給施行殺戮的人。

words.note: Refers to the northern kingdom of Israel.
Refers to the northern kingdom of Israel.

verses.text: 耶和華啊，求你賜給他們；你要賜給他們甚麼呢？求你使他們墜胎小產，乳房萎縮。

words.note: The Hebrew name for God.

verses.text: 「他們的一切罪惡都在吉甲，我在那裡憎恨他們，因他們的惡行，我要把他們從我的家裡趕出來；我不再愛他們，他們的領袖都是叛徒。

words.note: Combined character meanings don't directly explain 'leader'.

verses.text: 以法蓮被擊打，他們的根枯乾了，必不能再結果子。即使他們生產，我必殺死他們所生的愛子。」

words.note: Refers to the tribe of Ephraim.
Often used metaphorically in biblical texts.
Indicates completed action or change of state.
Expresses strong certainty or necessity.
Common idiom in the Bible, both literal and metaphorical.
Expresses strong certainty or necessity.
Turns the following verb into a nominal phrase: 'that which is V-ed'.
Often refers to an only or favored son, or a special relationship.

verses.text: 我的 神必棄絕他們，因為他們不聽從他；他們必在列國中飄流。

words.note: The preceding space is a reverent mark for the divine name/title.
Expresses strong certainty or necessity.
Stronger than simply 'discard'; implies a complete severance.
Often used in contexts of heeding advice or divine command.
Expresses strong certainty or necessity.
Often refers to the Gentile nations in biblical contexts.
Used as a postposition, often paired with '在' to indicate location.
Suggests aimless wandering, often associated with exile or displacement.
